messageBody:
Actually, Japanese is certainly not a language I would have picked for
the "Written Phonetically" award! It's true that the two syllabaries of
Japanese (you have to learn about a hundred symbols to get both
down) are phonetic ("phonemic" would be the better choice of words),
but you also have to learn hundreds of Chinese characters, each of which
may have two to half a dozen different pronunciations depending on their
context. Add to this that fact that some words (mostly words borrowed from
foreign languages) are written using the katakana syllabary and others
(particles
and endings and native roots) are written using hiragana, then throw in
letters
of the Latin alphabet here and there for foreign abbreviations and such, and
you have a system that I would term byzantine rather than phonetic. Probably
no language is perfect in this regard, but if I were passing out awards for
Best Orthography, I'd pick Spanish as the winner in the West and Korean
as the winner in the East. Speaking of ease of recognition, many Korean
kids learn to read before they go to kindergarten. This is not because
they're
smarter than English-speaking kids but because their spelling system is so
regular.

Gary Yu

>I just finished reading the article "The Science of Word Recognition "
>(by Kevin Larson) ... thanks for posting the link to the web site.
>
>With regard to the Read alphabet, I found this statement very interesting:
>
> "It is well known that words that have a consistent spelling to sound
>correspondence such as mint, tint, and hint are recognized faster than
>words that have an inconsistent spelling to sound correspondence such
>as pint."
>
>If this is true, given enough practice, we should be able to read text
>written in QuikScript more rapidly than text written in the normal,
>orthodox alphabet. Has anyone become proficient enough in reading
>QuikScript text that they would say they can read it faster than they
>can read regular text? Any estimates of how much time and practice it
>might take reach this level?
>
>Also, in some languages, words are spelled much more phonetically than
>is English (a quick search on the internet says German and Japanese
>are two such languages). Does anyone know whether or not people that
>use these languages can actually read at faster rates? Could the
>average German read a Harry Potter novel in less time than an average
>American?
